Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Forced-Air Warming Systems in Preventing Inadvertent Perioperative Hypothermia

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either the FAW group or the control group (no technology).

Participants.evidence: Adult patients undergoing surgery lasting over 30 minutes were eligible. This randomised controlled trial was conducted in a medium-large hospital in Northern Italy.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either the FAW group or the control group (no technology).

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the effectiveness and efficiency of Forced-Air Warming (FAW) systems compared to no warming technology.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of IPH-related adverse events, measured postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the FAW group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the FAW group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The FAW group showed a significant reduction in surgical site infections (3% vs. 12%), cardiac events (3.5% vs. 7.6%), and blood transfusions (6.2% vs. 7.4%).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.
